comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: A tragic disaster on a par with the Stardust (1981) yet strangely, I've not heard of the Drumcollogher cinema fire until now. I found this link that gives an account www.boards.ie/vbulletin/showthread.php?p=52026906 If I may add that film in those days were made of nitro cellulose which was extremely combustible.

comment.author: 36844288@N00
comment._content: I have to say, sadly, I'd never heard of this - and strange how, as I lived in Dublin at the time of the Stardust Disaster, I don't recall it being mentioned at the time. It is a powerful, evocative image.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: As a child I had heard of this from my parents and knew that a lot of people had lost their lived but the detail I had not heard other than the fact that the film took fire.  48 dead in a tiny village had to be a nightmare, I had been in the Stardust a week before the fire and  had occasion to be there in the immediate aftermath.  I knew some of the people who died there and the effects on their families so God knows how those in Drumcollogher ever got to terms with their tragedy.

comment.author: 58951644@N06
comment._content: We should never forget those poor people & their families in Drumcollogher  Ì live in N.C.W. a few miles away may they rest in peace

comment.author: 69179802@N08
comment._content: I recently came accross a number of cheques that would have been paid out to the relatives of people who had lost their lives in this disaster, are they of any use to anyone

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69179802@N08] Are you serious??!! If you don't want them, (and they are of no use to any of the relatives concerned) I would kill to have them for our NLI Ephemera Collections!!! Have a look at our other Flickr stream or on our website to see a small glimpse of the range of Ephemera in the National Library's collections... They'd be given a good home!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
